email.title: Weekly Digest
email.text:
Another week another digest!
We're sending off a week with some very successful and interesting industrial events from Microsoft and Bloomberg, as well as our Welcome Bar Night! Thank you to all who came to those and we hope you had fun!
This week, we bring you more internal events (and a breakfast!) with our sponsors, so read on.
email.heading: Volunteer at DoCSoc Events
email.text:
Attended our events? Have you wondered how we make them happen under the hood?
If you would like to be part of the organisation behind our industrial events and get to know sponsors or committee members, then go to docsoc.co.uk/volunteer and join the DoCSoc: Operations Facebook group for updates. Volunteering at events can get you recognition and experience that can one day earn you a spot in DoCSoc committee. If you have any queries ask us at docsoc@imperial.ac.uk!
email.heading: Create the DoC Banner Competition!
email.text:
Take a chance in winning a £20/£10 Amazon voucher and get a better banner for our department!
Did you know that our department uses this banner below at all its public events? It looks quite outdated, right? That is why we decided to partner with the department to have the competition of creating a better DoC banner! All you need to do is design a banner that follows all the requirements below and submit your design here! The winner will get a £20 Amazon voucher, while the runner-ups will get £10 Amazon vouchers.
[Click here to enter the competition!](https://forms.gle/cZP52Fx97N8JdN9t6)
**The deadline: 1st December 2019**
email.heading: 2019 Milner Award Lecture - Towards the Genomic Footprints of Life

event.location: The Royal Society, London, 6-9 Carlton House Terrace, London, SW1Y 5AG
event.text:
Milner Award Lecture 2019 given by Professor Eugene Myers.
We are about to enter an era of DNA technology where one can determine the genome sequence of any living animal or plant with near perfect fidelity for €1,000 or less. Already there are nascent projects such as the Vertebrate Genome Project (VGP) whose goal is to sequence every one of the more than 70,000 species of vertebrates currently extant on our planet. As such, this ability will revolutionize ecology, evolution, and conservation science and effectively mark the beginning of a new exploration of the natural world.
The lecture will start with a brief review of the history of DNA sequencing technology and the computational problems involved in interpreting the data so produced. This history begins with Fred Sanger’s sequencing of the virus “lambda” in 1980, continues to the sequencing of the Human genome in 2000, and culminates in the present with an introduction to the transformative technologies alluded to above. However, the primary hurdle in this future vision is actually computational and the issues and potential approaches to addressing them will be discussed. Professor Myers will present several recent findings enabled by having the genome sequences of related species and conclude with a prospectus of what could be discovered in the future.
The prize lecture will be webcast live and the video recording of the event will be available shortly after the event.

email.heading: Huxley Breakfast! Sponsored by Bank of America Merrill Lynch

event.text:
Get your week off to a great start with one of DoCSoc's free breakfasts - generously sponsored by Bank of America Merrill Lynch! Come along to Huxley 341/342 any time from 8am-10am and enjoy a great pre-lecture breakfast with other DoCSoc'ers and fellow MathSoc folk. So come on over, have a snack and meet with engineers from BAML!
If you have any specific dietary requirements, please let us know a few days beforehand!

email.heading: Reading Groups by Nuri Cingillioglu and Dr. Antoine Cully

event.text:
We are happy to announce that the Reading Groups are back! Reading Groups are lectures/panels where researchers talk about their current work, aimed at final and penultimate year undergraduate, as well as and postgraduate students. Our main goal for organising such talks is to expose students to different types of research in Computer Science. Our first 2 Reading Groups will be by Nuri Cingillioglu and Dr. Antoine Cully.
Reading Group by Dr. Antoine Cully 1 - 1.30pm
Title: Creative Learning algorithms for Resilient Robots
Abstract: Reinforcement learning algorithms are tightly linked with the optimisation of functions to find the best solution according to one or several objectives. Recently, we developed a new family of optimisation algorithms, named Quality-Diversity optimisation, that contrasts with classic algorithms. Instead of searching for a single solution, Quality-Diversity algorithms are searching for a large collection of both diverse and high-performing solutions. With this approach, robots are capable of finding creative solutions to overcome complicated situations, like loss of a leg. During this seminar, I will show several examples of applications of these algorithms.
Reading Group by Nuri Cingillioglu 1.30 - 2pm
Title: Computational Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning and how machines can learn elements of logical thinking
Abstract: "Can machines think?" - asked Alan Turing in his 1950 seminal paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence". Recent advances in deep learning are yielding great results across practical applications such as natural language processing, image recognition and reinforcement learning; however, how machines can incorporate elements of logical thought and learn to reason are open to research. Combining machine learning with logic-based expert systems in order to get the best of both worlds are becoming increasingly more popular. In this talk, I’ll give a brief overview of my involvement in the field of neuro-symbolic reasoning and discuss how the future of Artificial Thought is evolving.

email.heading: Palantir Decomposition Workshop

event.text:
At Palantir, we solve real-world problems. A big part of this is being able to break down a problem you aren’t familiar with, and coming up with creative and strategic solutions. This is what we call decomposition. Come join our workshop to learn more about how we problem solve and how to ace any technical interview! We will also be showing a live demo of our software in action.
We look forward to seeing you there!
This event will be catered with free pizza and soft drinks as usual! Please press GOING to help us gauge our food ordering requirements. If you have any specific dietary requirements, please let us know a few days beforehand by emailing docsoc@imperial.ac.uk
Please fill out this link as well if you are going to the event: https://palantir.recsolu.com/external/events/-VpzqQIxns4qxR8yKPulxA
_______
You must be a member of DoCSoc on the day of the event in order to participate. Computing, JMC, and EIE students are automatically DoCSoc members. Membership can be purchased for £30 at docsoc.co.uk/join.

email.heading: Netcraft - Credit Card Skimming for Fun and Profit

event.text:
JavaScript credit card skimmers are increasingly prevalent. Criminals break into online shopping websites and insert small snippets of JavaScript which steal a copy of credit card details and any other credentials as they are entered, sometimes receiving them even before the legitimate site processes the payment.
Strategies available to criminals include researching vulnerabilities in widely used commerce software, scanning across the internet to install their skimmer on all the matching shops worldwide and then securing the site so that other criminals are unable to do the same. Alternatively, criminals may try to find a vulnerability in a high traffic shop which alone might do as many transactions as the entire set of vulnerable installations of shopping platform such as WooCommerce or Magento.
To illustrate the scale of the opportunity, last year a skimmer were discovered on the British Airways' site after it had harvested an estimated 380,000 credentials. The Information Commissioner’s Office subsequently fined British Airways £183 million for the breach.
As part of the UK’s Active Cyber Defence (https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/news/annual-review-2019), Netcraft protects UK shoppers against JavaScript skimmers by continually searching for skimmers on shops hosted in the UK, notifying all the people in a position to influence the removal of the skimmer including the shop owner and hosting company. To date we have done over 2000 successful takedowns of JavaScript skimmers on British shops. Current DocSoc members have contributed significantly to the development of this service.
The Challenge
After a tutorial on JavaScript skimming, each team is given a shopping site to operate. A shopping bot makes purchases from each shop throughout the event. The aim is to keep your own shop free of skimmers so that it makes money through the shopping bot’s purchases, whilst attempting to install and maintain a skimmer on as many of the other contestants shops as possible and steal their transactions.
The team with the most money at the end of the event is the winner.
To take part, bring your own laptop with a web browser and an SSH client (e.g. Putty http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/ for Windows users; OpenSSH for Linux/Mac users).
Pizza and soft drinks will be provided during the event, followed by a Netcraft-sponsored bar night. This event is only for DoCSoc members. Netcraft’s previous workshops have been very popular, please make sure you press "Going" so we know how much food to order. If you have any specific dietary requirements, please let us know a few days beforehand by emailing docsoc@imperial.ac.uk

email.heading: Internship 101

event.text:
If you're currently looking for an internship, or simply want to know more about the internship process, come along to Internship 101 to find out about companies that are still hiring from past interns.
Gain an exclusive honest insider opinion, learn about the types of projects interns worked on and the interview process to give you the best chance of getting an offer!
This event will be held as a panel discussion with past interns from Google, Bloomberg and other companies. We tried to gather a diverse group of panellists who interned not only at banks and big tech companies but also smaller firms and startups.
If you have any questions that you would like to be answered during the panel, please submit them using this form: docsoc.co.uk/internship101-questions
This event will be catered with free pizza and soft drinks as usual! Please press GOING to help us gauge our food ordering requirements. If you have any specific dietary requirements, please let us know a few days beforehand by emailing docsoc@imperial.ac.uk
_______
You must be a member of DoCSoc on the day of the event in order to participate. Computing, JMC, and EIE students are automatically DoCSoc members. Membership can be purchased for £30 at docsoc.co.uk/join.

email.heading: Citadel - Challenge the Impossible

event.text:
Citadel is hosting an Information & Networking session on Thursday 31st Oct at Imperial!
If you're interested in learning more about the different roles in a leading trading firm and are looking to expand your career options, then come along in Lecture Theatre 201 in Skempton Building at 18:30 on the 31st.
For more information check out the attached PDF.
